Graphical abstract The preparation strategies, structure-property-function relationships and electrocatalytic applications of single-atom catalyst/heteroatom-doped carbons (SAC-HDPCs) have been reviewed. The outlook for the future of SAC-HDPC electrocatalysis is presented. Electrocatalysts play a crucial role in the development of renewable energy conversion and storage nanotechnologies. The unique advantages of heteroatom-doped porous carbon-supported single-atom electrocatalysts (SAC-HDPCs) are clear. These SAC-HDPCs exhibit outstanding activity, selectivity and stability due to their distinct electronic structure, satisfactory conductivity, controllable porosity and heteroatom-doping effect. Rapid and significant developments involving the synthesis, characterization, and structure-property-function relationship of SAC-HDPCs have been made in recent years. In this review, we describe recent research efforts involving advanced (in situ) characterization techniques, innovative synthetic strategies, and electrochemical energy conversion examples of SAC-HDPCs. The electrocatalytic performance of SAC-HDPCs is further considered at an atomic level, and the mechanisms underlying this performance are also discussed in detail. We expect that these analyses and deductions will be useful for the design of new materials and may help to establish a foundation for the design of future SAC-HDPCs. Keywords Carbon material Heteroatom doping Single-atom electrocatalyst Electrocatalytic energy conversion 1 Introduction On the occasion of the 125th anniversary of Science, 125 scientific problems were selected as the most challenging scientific issues, and two of these issues were associated with energy conversion on the topic of greenhouse gas emissions and replacement of fossil oil [1]. After 16 years of advancement, it is considered that the electrochemical conversion of chemical feedstocks into value-added products is a promising alternative solution to realize CO2-free energy conversion technologies [2–7]. Clearly, electrocatalysts play important roles in the development of green energy conversion technologies. Searching for suitable electrocatalysts for various energy conversion reactions represents one of the most active areas of current research [8]. When designing high-performance electrocatalysts, three critical factors must be considered: the physicochemical properties of the active center and the conductivity and porous state of the substrate [9,10]. The physicochemical properties of the catalytic center are mostly determined by its size and electronic structure. Downsizing metal catalysts from bulk to nanoparticles (NPs) and from clusters to single atoms (SAs) has shown promising results with regards to both activity and selectivity in various catalytic reactions [11–19]. Recently, single-atom electrocatalysts have attracted broad research interest because these single-atom active sites have 100% atom utilization, impressive activity and selectivity. In addition, these superior catalysts have a well-defined electronic environment, which facilitates the elucidation of reaction mechanisms and understanding of the structure–property-function relationships, as these catalysts are very similar to homogeneous catalytic systems [20]. In single-atom catalysts (SACs), apart from the innate physicochemical property of active single atoms, the catalytic activity of SACs is largely determined by the local environment [4,13,21–23]. In this regard, the judicious choice of SAC supports is crucial for the manufacture of SA-based electrocatalysts with specific uses and maximization of their functions. Among various supports of SACs (i.e., metal oxides, MoS2, and graphene), heteroatom-doped porous carbons (HDPCs) are particularly attractive due to their low cost, large surface areas, chemical stability and tunable conductivity [13,24]. The high conductivity of carbon materials favors fast charge transport and is a mandatory requirement for efficient electrocatalysis [25]. In addition, the porous structure of carbons clearly has profound effects on their properties and functions. The porosity of carbons reduces their apparent density and expands their surface area to accelerate mass transfer in electrocatalysis. Of particular interest is hierarchical pore architecture, in which micropores and mesopores are beneficial and provide active surface areas with high accessibility, and the macropores form interconnected three-dimensional networks and serve as transport highways to accelerate mass diffusion and significantly promote exchange efficiency. SAC-HDPCs are increasingly becoming the subject of intense study. Heteroatoms (i.e., N, P, S) or even different configurations of the same heteroatom in HDPCs can not only stabilize SAs on the carbons but also tailor the electronic structure of the active sites, thereby modulating the general catalytic performance of SACs [9,22,25–29]. For example, Hu et al. [30] demonstrated that pyrrolic N is beneficial to the stabilization of Fe3+ SAs in N-doped porous carbon, which displayed distinctively higher catalytic performance and long-term operational stability toward the electroreduction of CO2 to CO than pyridinic N-stabilized Fe2+ SACs between −0.2 and −0.5 V versus reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE); the activity of Fe3+ SACs became unstable when the potentials were more negative than −0.5 V (versus RHE), which could be attributed to the change in coordination environments (from pyrrolic N to pyridinic N) inducing the transformation of Fe3+ to Fe2+. In another example, Choi et al. [31] reported that sulfur-doped carbon can stabilize a relatively high content of single-atom platinum (5 wt%). In the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), this catalyst could selectively produce H2O2 with excellent long-term operational stability. Recently, p-block elements (especially including semimetallic B and Se) have emerged as a new type of SAC-HDPC that can form stable covalent bonds with carbon, which is fundamentally different from heteroatom-coordinated and defect-stabilized SACs [32]. In this new type of SAC, in addition to the intrinsic electronic structure of p-block elements, the integration of additional heteroatom(s) into the carbon matrix could cause structural distortions and change the electronic band structure, which alters the overall physicochemical characteristics of porous carbon materials (i.e., the thermal stability and electronic properties), thereby regulating the overall electrocatalytic activity and operational durability of SAC-HDPCs [9]. Attaining well-defined SAC-HDPCs and understanding their structure–property-function relationships is a desirable goal in the development of efficient SAC-HDPCs. In this review, we present an overview of the synthesis, characterization, and structure–property-function relationship of SAC-HDPCs, centering on their applications in electrochemical energy conversion. We begin by concisely analyzing the advanced characterization techniques of SACs. Second, we provide a comprehensive understanding of the preparation techniques of SAC-HDPCs, including heteroatom-coordination interactions, porous confinement effects, and p-block elements. Third, we demonstrate the most representative examples in their electrochemical applications, including the ORR, oxygen evolution reaction (OER), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR), and energy conversion devices, as well as the underlying mechanisms, obtaining critical insights on the impact of the local environment of SAC-HDPCs. Finally, the challenges and future directions to design SAC-HDPCs for electrocatalytic energy conversion applications are discussed. 2 Advance characterization techniques Traditionally, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) have been utilized to visualize the overall morphology and confirm the presence of incorporated species on carbon materials. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Raman spectroscopy can further provide insights into the electronic structures of each element and structural information of carbon materials. These technologies are very mature in characterizing conventional carbon-based nanomaterials. However, it becomes much more challenging for traditional electron microscopy to directly observe these alien species at the atomic level. In addition, the low content of SAs in SAC-HDPCs makes conventional characterization techniques less effective or even unable to precisely detect these atomically dispersed atoms. In this regard, it is necessary to begin by noting what characterization techniques have already been utilized to characterize the locations, atomic configurations and distribution of these single atoms inside the carbon framework, since these parameters play vital roles in determining their physicochemical properties and final performances. In this section, the most relevant characterization techniques will be systematically expatiated. 2.1 Scanning transmission electron microscopy It is believed that directly visualizing the immobilized SA on the carbon supports is probably the most convincing and intuitive strategy. Conventional electron microscopies such as SEM or TEM are generally capable of reaching the nano- or subnanoscale. However, these technologies fail to provide meaningful results for SACs. To achieve higher resolution of the scanning images, TEM is usually equipped with the scanning mode (STEM) to provide better insight into the atomic location and configuration of each element inside the carbon materials. In comparison to traditional TEM, STEM uses a rastered beam mode, and the electron beam can be focused on a diameter as small as 0.1 nm by the condenser lenses, achieving the finest possible probe size (0.5 Å) [33]. Therefore, STEM enables atomic-scale resolution for the imaging and chemical analysis of various SAs on carbon materials. STEM images are formed by filtering the scattered electrons over a certain angular range, which usually involve either bright-field (BF) or dark-field (DF) imaging models. Briefly, the region in the sample with a higher atomic number (Z) element will appear relatively dark in the BF because a high proportion of incident electrons are scattered. On the other hand, the DF image is formed by accepting the scattered electrons, and the higher Z elements will result in a brighter signal on the images. This technology enabled the rapid observation of heavy (semi)-metals. For example, atomically dispersed various metal atoms can be directly visualized in the carbon matrix by high-angle annular dark field-STEM (HAADF-STEM), which were observed as bright dots through the carbon matrix (Fig. 1 a and b) [34]. Notably, atomic structures within single-layer graphene can be clearly resolved, and the observed coordination configurations of the atomic metals apparently match well with the MN4C4 moieties derived from X-ray adsorption fine structure spectroscopy (XAFS) studies (Fig. 1c–e) (which will be discussed later). In addition, atomically dispersed semimetal Se atoms located at edge sites of the carbon nanosheet membrane could also be clearly differentiated by HAADF-STEM images [35]. Se atoms were presented as bright dots (Fig. 1f and g). 2.2 Atom probe tomography Direct differentiation of Ag and Pd elements in Ag–Pd core shell structures by TEM mapping is impossible because of their similar atomic numbers. In this regard, the atom probe tomography method is highly useful. For example, Tsang et al. [36] utilized the atom probe tomography (APT) technique to successfully identify both Ag and Pd atoms in core–shell structures (Fig. 1h). The working principle of APT is based on an ion-sensitive detector that can directly detect additional short (ns) pulse ions generated by high electric fields. The atomic-scale resolution of APT enables the identification of adjacent elements in the periodic table. Meanwhile, the exact composition of Ni atoms on graphene could be accurately revealed using the APT method [37]. In the projected 2D image (Fig. 1i–k), the Ni atoms coordinated in graphene vacancies were directly observed. Statistics and quantitative analysis showed that 83% of Ni was present as single atoms, but only 0.2% was coordinated with neighboring N atoms. 2.3 Synchrotron radiation technique X-ray adsorption fine structure spectroscopy (XAFS) measurements can be utilized to characterize the local environment and chemical state of SAs in carbons. Depending on the local environment, the electronic structure of SAs is utterly different. Fine structure spectroscopy is commonly divided into two regions: The near-edge region (XANES or EXAFS) within ca. 50 eV and extended fine structures (EXAFS) that may extend up to more than 1000 eV above the edge [38]. XANES is very sensitive to the electronic structures of SAs, while the EXAFS region is focused on the distance and number of neighboring atoms. For example, the Fourier transform (FT) EXAFS spectrum revealed that the Co atoms in Co phthalocyanine on hollow N-doped porous carbon spheres (Co–N5/HNPCSs) were coordinated with N [39]. The XANES spectrum suggests the positive charge characteristics of the Co atoms with valence states between + 2 and + 3. Fe-SA coordinated with dual N and P in carbons could also be accurately characterized by XANES and EXAFS (Fig. 2 ) [40]. In comparison with different Fe species, the coordination configuration of Fe-SA was suggested to be Fe–H4 (H: heteroatom) in a square planar structure with a valence state between + 2 and + 3. The FT EXAFS spectrum indicated a prominent peak at 1.53 Å, which is attributed to Fe–H bonds and is similar to Fe phthalocyanine (Fig. 2c and d). With the aid of simulation analysis, the existence of Fe–N/–P SACs was confirmed (Fig. 2e and f). 2.4 Various in situ characterization techniques With the development of various in situ characterization techniques, monitoring the reaction process of SACs has become feasible during their practical usage [41]. In 2011, Zhang et al. [42] utilized in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (in situ FTIR) to directly observe the weak interaction between Pt-SACs and CO gas under different pressures, which is very different from the signal of bridged-bonded CO − Pt clusters. These results unambiguously confirmed the different physicochemical properties and reaction dynamics of Pt-SACs and Pt clusters toward CO oxidation. In addition, in situ TEM is also a powerful tool to monitor the formation process of SACs or even the reaction process during their practical use. As shown in Fig. 3(a), the transformation of Pd NPs to thermally stable single Pd atoms was observed above 900 °C under an inert atmosphere by in situ environmental TEM (ETEM) [43]. The Pd NPs undergo an intensive collision within the carbon supports, eventually coordinate to the nearby N atoms and finally form thermally stable Pd-SACs. In this process, atomization and agglomeration of the Pd atoms coexist, but the presence of coordinated atoms, such as N, could stabilize Pd atoms to prevent their agglomeration. Experimental results with DFT calculations revealed that the most stable Pd atoms were coordinated with two pyrrolic and pyridinic N atoms at defect sites, highlighting the key role of heteroatoms in carbons for the formation of stable SACs (Fig. 3b). To further gather electronic information about SACs during their actual application, operando (in situ) X-ray adsorption spectroscopy has recently emerged as an effective tool to monitor the active sites and dynamic behavior of the electronic environment of SAs [18,41]. During the electrochemical CO2 reduction process, Liu et al. [44] observed a 0.4 eV shift toward higher energy Ni-SACs, which indicates that spontaneous charge transfer from Ni to CO2 increases the oxidation state of Ni species. After one cycle of CO2 reduction, the Ni K-edge spectrum again shifts back to a lower energy, indicative of the excellent stability of Ni active sites (Fig. 3c). In addition, the main peak of EXAFS is shifted ~ 0.04 Å during CO2 reduction, suggesting the expansion of the Ni–N bond due to the redistribution of the electrons in the Ni 3d orbital (Fig. 3d). These advances in situ characterization techniques undoubtedly sharpen our understanding of the mechanisms of various SACs. 3 Construction of SAC-HDPC electrocatalysts The local environment of active SAs has a significant impact on their functions. In this context, the synthetic strategies of SAC-HDPC electrocatalysts involving heteroatom-coordination interactions, porous confinement effects and p-block elements are discussed in this section. The recent advancement of noble metal-, transition metal- and emerging semimetal-based SAC-HDPCs was also outlined (see Table 1 ). 3.1 Heteroatom-coordination interaction Due to the intrinsic high surface energy of SACs, atomically dispersed metal atoms tend to aggregate and form clusters or nanoparticles during their synthesis and applications. Therefore, one of the most common strategies to effectively prevent the migration of these metal atoms is by introducing electron-rich elements such as N and S in carbon to coordinate and immobilize the movement of electron-deficient metals. 3.1.1 Wet impregnation method In wet chemistry strategies, N- or S-doped carbons can effectively anchor metal ions to minimize the formation of metal clusters or NPs. For example, Choi and colleagues [31] constructed atomically dispersed Pt-SAs in S-doped porous carbon by the impregnation of H2PtCl6 on S-doped carbon supports followed by H2 reduction. With increasing S content in carbon, it was found that downsizing the NPs to Pt clusters and then Pt-SACs was achieved. The Pt-SACs exhibited outstanding activity and selectivity toward producing H2O2 in the ORR. Employing a homogenous solution of dicyandiamide and Pd salts as carbonization precursors, N atom-stabilized Pd-SACs could be readily obtained by the direct pyrolysis of freeze-dried solid powders, which displayed excellent catalytic performance toward acetylene hydrogenation [51]. Li et al. [39] recently employed N-doped hollow carbon spheres as electron donors to successfully fabricate Co-SACs. By soaking N-doped hollow carbon spheres in Co phthalocyanine solution, the coordination between Co and N-doped hollow carbon spheres finally affords Co–N5 N-doped carbon electrocatalysts due to the intrinsic electron-deficient nature of Co phthalocyanine (Fig. 4 a–e). Similarly, graphdiyne (GDY) possesses strong electron donating properties that can also be utilized to immobilize metal atoms. Lu et al. [47] constructed SACs on GDY via the coordination interaction between Pt atoms and alkynl C atoms by impregnating GDY in K2PtCl4 aqueous solution. After thermal annealing, these Pt atoms were found to be coordinated with the carbon atoms and formed C1–Pt–Cl4 and C2–Pt–Cl3 structures. Interestingly, the four coordinated Pt-SACs (C1–Pt–Cl4) displayed higher catalytic performance than conventional Pt/C and five coordinated catalysts (C2–Pt–Cl3). The intrinsic advantages of wet impregnation method are closely related to its easy operation. By utilizing the strong coordination ability of the electron rich heteroatoms such as N or S, SACs with high loading can be achieved. 3.1.2 Direct pyrolysis Direct pyrolysis is widely employed to construct SAC-HDPCs because of the abundant carbon and heteroatom sources in the precursors (i.e., metal containing small molecules, polymers, and MOFs). During the pyrolysis process, such heteroatoms as N and S could effectively coordinate with active metal atoms to prevent the migration of these metal atoms to the formation of NPs or clusters. Utilizing heteroatom-laden polymers as carbon sources to fabricate SAC-HDPCs is fascinating because these polymers can first be processed into complicated structures and then build selective porous networks via intrinsic phase separation. At the same time, with the aid of heteroatoms, the electronic structures of HDPCs can be rationally tailored for designated applications [9]. Polymers including heteroatom-rich polymers or covalent organic polymers/frameworks (COPs/COFs) are all suitable precursors to fabricate SAC-HDPCs. For example, Lou et al. [65] prepared Pt-SAs loaded on N-doped carbons by employing N containing polydopamine (PDA) as a precursor (Fig. 4f). In this work, polymer spheres were prefunctionalized with Pt salts, and the subsequent carbonization process relocated the Pt atoms from the surface to the interior of the carbon matrix. Due to the high abundance of N atoms, the Pt atoms were effectively coordinated and formed isolated Pt-SAs rather than Pt NPs or clusters during the carbonization process. Chen et al. [66] prepared Fe-SACs based on a polymerization-pyrolysis-evaporation strategy. In the first step, a Zn/Fe coordinated polymer network was synthesized via a low-temperature solvent-free solid phase process. By adjusting the ratio of Zn and Fe (the presence of Zn atoms could effectively prevent the aggregation of Fe atoms during the pyrolysis process), pyrolysis of the polymers led to Fe-SAs on the N-doped carbons. Ji et al. [67] developed an efficient approach to construct SACs via a precursor-dilution strategy. In this work, various metal cations were first chelated with tetraphenylporphyrin. Tetraphenylporphyrin could efficiently separate neighboring metal atoms, ensuring the formation of SAs on N-doped carbons after pyrolysis at 600 °C under a N2 atmosphere. In another work, Wan et al. [68] prepared various SACs by a cascade anchoring strategy (Fig. 4g). The glucose chelating agent can effectively sequester metal ions and subsequently bind to an O-rich carbon support. After pyrolysis, the N atoms bind to the metal atoms to form M−N x moieties. This method could lead to SACs with high loading contents up to 12.1 wt%. Taking MOFs as carbonization precursors to construct SAC-HDPCs is a subject of intense study. The unique porous structures and rich N atoms of MOFs induced a space-confinement effect and effectively coordinated metal atoms, facilitating the formation of SACs after one-step pyrolysis. For example, Chen et al. [69] recently successfully prepared Ir-SAC-HDPCs by the direct carbonization of Ir-impregnated ZIF-8. During the carbonization process, the Zn atoms evaporated above 900 °C, and Ir-SAC-HDPCs were formed by the space-confinement effect of micropores and N coordination interaction with Ir. Xu et al. [70] prepared Ru-SAC-HDPCs by the pyrolysis of Ru containing ZIF-8 (Fig. 5 a). ZIF-8 has a cavity diameter of 11.6 Å and can effectively uptake Ru(acac)3 with a diameter of 10.4 Å. During carbonization, Zn nodes evaporate, leaving N-rich domains to stabilize Ru atoms. In another example, Li et al. [55] constructed Ru SACs by utilizing UiO-66-NH2 as a host to impregnate Ru precursors. In contrast, without the aid of NH2 groups, Ru clusters were formed during pyrolysis. The introduction of an NH2 moiety is believed to largely limit the diffusion of Ru atoms during their pyrolysis, thereby leading to well-separated Ru metal atoms (Fig. 5b). Eventually, the ZrO2 nanoparticles were etched by HF, resulting in Ru SAs on N-doped carbons. 3.1.3 Template-assisted pyrolysis A template-assisted pyrolysis method with the aid of heteroatom coordination has been effectively developed to construct high-performance SAC-HDPCs. This approach can simultaneously control both the morphology and porosity of the SAC-HDPCs, which is favorable for improving specific catalytic reactions. The pyrolysis of porphyrindine-coated SiO2 NPs and porous Co-SACs could be easily obtained by etching with NaOH [71]. These catalysts exhibited excellent ORR activity even comparable to that of state-of-the-art Pt/C. In another example, Shui et al. [72] first prepared Fe-SAC-HDPCs with largely enhanced porosity and external surface area by the pyrolysis of mesoporous SiO2-coated ZIF-8 at 650 °C followed by the removal of the SiO2 layer (Fig. 5c). Due to the unique electrostatic absorption between positively charged [Fe(Phen)3]2+ and negatively charged N-doped carbon hosts, the [Fe(Phen)3]2+ complex could be homogenously encapsulated in the N-doped carbon porous networks (Fig. 5d–f). Taking these Fe-SAC-HDPCs as proton exchange membrane fuel cell electrodes, the device exhibited an impressed power density of 1.18 W cm−2 under 2.5 bar H2–O2 and an activity of 129 mA cm−2 at 0.8 ViR-free under 1.0 bar H2–air, which meets the 2018Pt-group metal-free catalyst activity target. These notable results could be attributed to the exposed inaccessible active sites (Fe–N4 moieties) and high surface area of Fe-SAC-HDPCs (650 m2 g−1) that enhanced the mass transport of the catalyst layer. 3.2 Porous confinement effect 3.2.1 Wet impregnation method In addition to the coordination strategy, defect sites in carbon materials could also be utilized to immobilize metal atoms to form SAC-HDPCs. In an early study, Zhang et al. [73] demonstrated a two-step process to create vacancies on graphene by high-energy atom/ion bombardment for selective doping with single metal atoms. Via the high binding energy of the metal-vacancy interaction, vacancy-laded graphene could be successfully doped with single metal atoms (i.e., Pt, Co and In). Defect-laded commercial carbon black is also an excellent supporter to fabricate single-atom electrocatalysts [46]. By an incipient wetness impregnation method, Ni-SAs loaded on defective graphene can be readily obtained [74]. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), Ni2+ was first adsorbed on the defective graphene sheets, followed by thermal annealing reduction and acid washing to afford Ni-SACs. With the aid of HAADF-STEM, Ni-SAs appeared to be bright dots in the carbon matrix (Fig. 6b and c). Notably, defect-stabilized SACs can be directly observed in the high-resolution HAADF-STEM images (Fig. 6d–g). Via linear fitting analysis of XANES, the ratio of curve intensities of Ni anchored on Di-vacancy, D5775 and perfect hexagons was found to be 36:44:20. Hu et al. [75] reported a general approach to construct different SACs by repeated on/off high-temperature shockwaves. In this work, different metal ion precursors were first loaded onto defective carbon, followed by rapid heating and quenching to form SACs (Fig. 7 a–e). Rapid heating and quenching processes were crucial to obtain highly dispersed SAs. The rapid high temperature provided the activation energy for atomic dispersion by forming thermodynamically stable metal-defect bonds, and the off state ensured overall stability. This strategy is scalable and may be significant for the preparation of thermally durable SACs. 3.2.2 Atomic layer deposition Direct deposition of metal precursors on defective carbon matrices is also an effective method to afford SAs on carbons. Atomic layer deposition (ALD) is based on a sequence of self-terminating reactions between gaseous precursors and carbon supports. The beauty of this strategy is that it allows homogeneous deposition of active materials on the substrates. These anchor sites could be either electron-rich heteroatoms [76], carbon defects or both. In the case of defects, Lu et al. [77] utilized the ALD technique to successfully construct Pd SAs on defective graphene oxide. The anchor sites on graphene were created by harsh sulfuric acid oxidation reactions, which enable exclusive nucleation of Pt atoms on the edges and line defects (Fig. 7f). It should be noted that the ALD technique is capable of controlling the size of metal atoms. For example, by controlling the deposition cycles, Sun et al. [49] successfully deposited Pt atoms ranging from SA clusters to nanoparticles on N-doped carbons. 3.2.3 Low-temperature synthesis Controlling the thermodynamics and kinetics of the nuclei formation process of metal precursors, Wu et al. [59,78] demonstrated a temperature controlled wet chemistry strategy to load transition metal (TM)-SA on carbons. In their approach, atomically dispersed Pt-SACs were realized by photochemical reduction at a rather low temperature. Typically, an aqueous solution of Pt precursor was frozen by liquid nitrogen and underwent subsequent UV irradiation. The solution was then mixed with carbons, leading to Pt-SA anchored on carbon defects. In a subsequent study by the same group employing a water/alcohol mixture with a low freezing point, liquid phase reduction of a Co precursor on N-doped carbon with hydrazine was achieved at −60 °C to form Co-SAs on the N-doped carbon [59]. 3.3 P-block element Semimetals are prone to forming bonds with carbon atoms during carbonization. During high-temperature pyrolysis, semimetallic SACs (SM-SACs) can bond to an abundance of carbon atoms inside the carbon framework, which effectively prevents atomic migration and forms stable SM-SACs. This specific feature is particularly interesting in the construction of SACs and has recently emerged as a new type of promising SAC for multiple energy-related fields. In 2019, Wang’s group [35] successfully incorporated atomically dispersed Se atoms into porous carbon membranes by the direct carbonization of a poly(ionic liquid) (PIL) membrane bearing Se(CN)2 − as a counteranion (Fig. 8 ). These semimetallic Se atoms were bonded to the adjacent carbons and uniformly dispersed throughout the carbon framework. Atomic incorporation of Se atoms in the carbon membrane not only enlarges the interlayer spacing of graphitic domains but also creates micropores due to the evaporation of Se atoms during the high-temperature pyrolysis process. XANES shows that the Se atom carries a positive charge, the valence state of which is between 0 and +4. It is generally considered that positively charged species in carbons are active sites, in this case, Se atoms. Employing these Se-SA-laden carbon membranes as electrodes for hydrazine fuel cells, the devices exhibited an open-circuit potential, maximum current density and power density of 0.91 V, 605.3 mA cm−2 and 182.2 mW cm−2, respectively. Such excellent device performance could be attributed to the ample Se SA active centers and large BET surface area that facilitate mass transfer. For Sn- and Sb-based SACs, heteroatoms such as N were required to stabilize these P-block elements. Strasser et al. [79] prepared Sn-SACs by multiple pyrolysis and acid leaching processes. These Sn-SACs exhibited excellent ORR performance (turnover frequency, TOF of 0.15 e site−1 s−1), which is even superior to that of famous Fe-SACs. Unlike Se-SACs (in which Se was bonded with C), (FT) EXAFS showed that SnN x existed in the Sn-SACs through the coordination of Sn and N atoms. In 2019, Sun et al. [80] prepared Sb-SAs on N-doped carbons by the direct pyrolysis of SbCl3 and urea on an active carbon block under argon conditions for a CO2RR. Without the aid of urea, only Sb nanoparticles were found during the synthesis, confirming that coordination with N sites was crucial to obtain Sb-SACs. P-block-SACs, as an emerging branch of SACs, have begun to gain prominence in various energy conversion reactions. Several recent theoretical studies have demonstrated that atomically dispersed B atoms on carbon have exceptional electrocatalytic activity toward N2 fixation [81,82]. Moreover, the nonmetallic main group element single-iodine-atom electrocatalysts reported by Qiao et al. [83] also showed outstanding performance toward the HER. We envision that these main group elements may become the next routes for the development of SACs. 4 Toward efficient energy conversion The burning of fossil fuels is probably the most well-established approach to generate high amounts of energy to meet the requirements of everyday usage. However, with the ever-increasing consumption of fossil fuels, massive emissions of greenhouse gases have raised numerous concerns associated with climate change and environmental issues. In this context, alternative sustainable energy sources and highly efficient energy harvesting technologies must be considered. In this chapter, we demonstrate the most representative examples of the energy conversion of SAC-HDPCs. The electrocatalytic performance of SAC-HDPCs is further considered at an atomic level, and the underlying mechanisms are also carefully discussed. 4.1 Electrocatalysis In heterogeneous catalysis, the size of the catalyst plays an indispensable role in determining the catalytic performance. Catalytic reactions only occur on the surface of catalysts. SACs with theoretical 100% atom utilization could provide ideal catalytic efficiency and selectivity toward specific reactions. Due to their intrinsic high conductivity, low cost, large surface area and chemical stability, heteroatom-doped carbon materials are promising supports for electrochemically active species. Taking these metrics together, SAC-HDPC electrocatalysts are becoming a heavily researched subject. 4.1.1 ORR With increasing energy demand and the sense of pursuing environmental energy conversion technology, fuel cells are considered one of the most promising approaches [84,85]. A fuel cell readily converts chemical energy into electricity with zero emissions. In a fuel cell, the ORR at the cathode plays a significant role in determining the overall device performance. In the ORR process, O2 is reduced to H2O by a four-electron pathway. In practical fuel cells, a two-electron pathway should be avoided because the poor electron transfer efficiency significantly lowers the device performance. In contrast, an exclusive two-electron pathway produces clean H2O2. In this regard, SACs with maximized atom utilization and high selectivity are expected to provide new opportunities toward practical applications. Sun’s group demonstrated that Pt-SAs on N-doped carbon electrocatalysts acting as cathodes in acidic single cells displayed remarkable power densities up to 680 mW cm−2 [45]. Density function theory (DFT) calculations showed that O2 adsorbed on the single Pt atoms assumed a side-on configuration. The elongated longer O−O bond (1.49 Å) on single Pt atoms indicated that O2 molecules could be more easily broken on Pt-SAs than their NP counterparts. In addition, H2O2 could be decomposed into two OH−, which facilitates the four-electron pathway. Furthermore, Pt-SAs on N-doped carbons displayed significantly higher adsorption energy toward O2 in comparison to CO, indicative of excellent stability against the CO poisoning effect. In sharp contrast, Choi et al. [31] demonstrated that S in porous carbons coordinated Pt-SACs following a two-electron pathway and displayed remarkable ORR selectivity toward the production of H2O2. According to DFT calculations (Fig. 9 a–h), the four-electron pathway was effectively suppressed due to the significantly higher kinetic barrier, leading to an exclusive two-electron pathway. Moreover, the calculated thermodynamic energy required to bind H2O2 to the atomically dispersed Pt sites was substantially too high, indicating that the Pt atoms were inactive in decomposing H2O2. However, for Pt atoms stabilized N-atoms, owing to the side-on configuration between O2 and Pt atoms. The decomposition into OH− is much favorable, leading efficient four-electron pathway. These results unambiguously demonstrate the effect of coordination environments of Pt single atoms on the selectivity of the ORR. Jiang et al. [58] recently reported that MOF-derived Fe-SACs displayed remarkable ORR activity and stability, surpassing all nonnoble metals and state-of-the-art Pt/Cs in both alkaline and acidic environments. The outstanding ORR activity is attributed to the hierarchical porous structures and high loading of single Fe active sites. In the DFT calculation from Li’s group, the rate-determining step of Fe-SACs for the ORR was identified as the last reduction step (RDS) (Fig. 9i–k) [86]. At the RDS, the Fe-SACs exhibited a rather low overpotential of 0.65 V, considerably lower than the 1.76 V for its nanoparticle counterpart, indicating that the high reactivity of Fe-SACs on the ORR was mainly attributed to the easier electron transfer from Fe single atoms to the adsorbed *OH species (Fig. 9l). To directly demonstrate the doping effect on the SACs, Lee et al. [87] tailored the ORR activity of Fe-SACs by rationally tuning the electronic structure of the surrounding environment. Particularly, by introducing electron-withdrawing S into the carbon plane, the d-band center of iron was inevitably decreased, thereby weakening the absorption of ORR intermediates and facilitating the ORR activity. In contrast, with the introduction of electron-donating thiophene-like S, the d-band center was upshifted, thereby forming a stronger interaction between Fe active sites and adsorbates (Fig. 9m and n). Three different free energy diagrams of ORR pathways were calculated to elucidate the roles of S functionalities on Fe-SACs. Different S species displayed different energies for H2O formation. In reaction pathway 1, the oxidized S-functionalized Fe-SACs exhibited exothermic reaction energy, while thiophene-like S-functionalized and pristine Fe-SACs showed unfavorable endothermic reaction energies (Fig. 9o–r). These theoretical calculations were in good agreement with the experimental results, demonstrating the crucial role of the electronic structures of SACs in determining the ORR performance. Other TM-SACs, such as Co-SACs [88,89], Ni-SACs [90], Mn-SACs [91], Cu-SACs [92] and Cr-SACs [93], also displayed excellent ORR electrocatalytic activity. At the same time, the porous structure of heteroatom-doped carbon along with the electronic structures of the SACs together play key roles in determining the electrocatalytic performance of SAC-HDPCs. Therefore, by optimizing both the carbon support and electronic structure of SACs, efficient and stable ORR electrocatalysts can be rationally designed. 4.1.2 HER Hydrogen is a clean, renewable energy carrier that has been actively pursued as an alternative to fossil fuels. Sustainable production of hydrogen from water splitting is an appealing solution yet requires a highly efficient, long-term stable electrocatalyst. Currently, Pt-based catalysts have been regarded as the best and most practical electrocatalysts due to their remarkable performance. However, the low abundance and high cost of Pt largely limit its practical applications [94]. To address these dilemmas, Pt-SACs with comparably lower loading but exhibiting nearly 100% atom utilization efficiency and superior catalytic performance have been developed. At the same time, transition metal-based SACs as alternative materials have also shown promise in the replacement of costly Pt-based catalysts. As a direct comparison, Sun et al. [49] demonstrated that N-anchored Pt-SACs displayed 37 times enhanced catalytic activity and high stability toward the HER in acidic environments compared with commercially available Pt/C catalysts. The unoccupied 5d orbitals of Pt atoms strongly interacted with the 1s orbital of H atoms, which was believed to be responsible for the excellent catalytic activity for the HER. Similarly, Lu et al. [47] prepared atomically dispersed Pt atoms on graphdiyne by engineering coordination environments. They found that four-coordinated Pt-SACs displayed 3 times higher catalytic activity than five-coordinated Pt-SACs. According to DFT calculations, the Gibbs free energy of H* on five-coordinated Pt-SACs displayed a significantly larger adsorption energy, which is highly unfavorable for the HER process. Recently, Song et al. [48] demonstrated that atomically dispersed Pt atoms on curved carbon displayed notably higher activity than conventional graphene-supported Pt-SACs or Pt/C catalysts (Fig. 10 a–c). According to the DFT calculation, the Gibbs free energy of H* (ΔG) on curved carbon supports approaches zero with increasing absorbed hydrogens, which is a prerequisite for efficient HER catalysts. Utilizing the Gouy-Chapman-Stern model, a high concentration of protons was found to be distributed around the Pt site, which was induced by the local electric field (Fig. 10c). These results clearly demonstrated that the local environments of SACs play an indispensable role in determining the HER. Due to the low cost and high earth abundance, nonnoble metal-based electrocatalysts have been widely developed for the HER. However, their sluggish reaction kinetics could not meet the standard of practical application. With the engineering coordination environment and electronic structures of SACs, it was found that TM-SACs show great potential for real-life HER applications. For example, in 2015, Chen et al. [95] successfully prepared atomically dispersed Ni on nanoporous graphene. The Ni-SACs displayed a low overpotential of approximately 50 mV and a Tafel slope of 45 mV dec−1 for the HER in acidic media. These performance metrics are comparable to that of commercial Pt/C-HER. According to DFT calculations, the efficient HER performance was attributed to the fast charge transfer between Ni and surrounding carbon atoms. Later, in 2016, Yao et al. [96] similarly demonstrated the remarkably efficient HER performance of Ni-SACs with a high exchange current density of 1.2 mA cm−2, which was the same magnitude as the value of state-of-the-art Pt/C. Most HER electrocatalysts are known to work efficiently under strongly acidic conditions simply because the large amount of H+ facilitates the HER process for thermodynamic and kinetic reasons [97]. Actually, producing H2 in alkaline media via the HER is preferable, as it offers high-purity H2 and simplifies the oxygen production side. However, the poisoning effects of hydroxide on the active sites and sluggish water dissociation step largely hinder their real-life application. Recently, Wei and colleagues [98] constructed Co-SACs and identified the dynamic structure of catalytically active sites in the HER under alkaline conditions. Operando X-ray spectroscopy and FTIR characterizations demonstrated that the atomically dispersed Co sites have strong chemical absorption of OH− under electrochemical conditions (Fig. 10d–g). According to the electron density difference plot of the OH adsorption structure on Co-SACs, the Co atom could donate its electron density to the nearby N and OH− groups through orbital hybridization. This efficient electron transfer makes the Co atoms more positive under working conditions and hence enhances the catalytic activity. 4.1.3 OER The electrocatalytic OER occurs at the anode in the water splitting process, which is essential for diverse clean energy technologies, such as CO2RR and metal-air batteries [99,100]. Noble metal-based catalysts (i.e., RuO2 and IrO2) are the benchmark OER electrocatalysts. However, these noble metals are extremely expensive and scarce in nature, which largely limits their practical commercialization. Regrettably, transition metal-based OER electrocatalysts usually suffer from sluggish kinetics, thereby restricting their energy conversion efficiency. Recently, with the rapid advancement in SAC technology, numerous SAC-HDPCs have been developed for efficient OERs by engineering their electronic environment. Huang and colleagues [34] prepared a series of atomically dispersed transition metals (Fe, Co and Ni) on N-doped graphene with a MN4C4 configuration for the OER. Via detailed XAFS analysis and DFT calculations, and the reaction mechanisms for Fe-, Co– and Ni-SACs were proposed (Fig. 11 a and b). In contrast to Fe- and Co-SACs, Ni-SACs displayed a unique dual-site mechanism, in which O* and OH* preferred to reside at the C sites and OOH* was absorbed on the Ni atom. By comparison of the energy barrier of each SAC, it was found that Ni-SACs with a dual site mechanism displayed the lowest energy barrier, suggesting that they had the most catalytic activity for the OER. In combination with experimental results and theoretical calculations, they deduced that the OER performance followed the trend of Ni > Co > Fe (Fig. 11c–e). At a 0.3 V overpotential, Ni-SACs exhibited one of the highest TOF values, representing one of the most active OER catalysts (Fig. 11f). To further understand the intrinsic high activity of Ni-SAs on N-doped carbons, the detailed electronic structures of Ni and N atoms were unveiled by Lou et al. [101], in which electron redistribution between Ni and N was clearly observed. Such Ni–N electronic coupling could shift down the Fermi level and facilitate the desorption of adsorbates, thus enhancing the OER kinetics, which is a representative example showing the doping effect on the SACs. Such Ni–N electronic coupling could shift down the Fermi level and facilitate the desorption of adsorbates, thus enhancing the OER kinetics, which is a representative example showing the doping effect on the SACs. Other examples from Wu [102] and Wang’s group [103] simultaneously demonstrated that the introduction of coordinated S atoms in Co– and Fe-SACs is beneficial to the OER. In addition to the coordination environment of SACs, Yao et al. [74] recently demonstrated that defects trapped with Ni-SA on graphene exhibited superior OER performance, even superior to that of IrO2 catalysts. According to their DFT calculations, the remarkable electrocatalytic OER activity was ascribed to the unique configuration of atomic Ni in the defects, which effectively modified the electronic structures of Ni–C and thereby lowered the reaction energy barrier. These results demonstrated the crucial role of the local environment in the achievement of high-performance SACs. 4.1.4 CO2RR Electrochemical reduction of CO2 in aqueous solution into value-added chemical feedstocks is of great significance for both environmental remediation and economic benefit [104]. Although great achievements have been made, practical implementation of the CO2RR in aqueous media is still a challenge because existing electrocatalysts suffer from one or more of the following problems: poor selectivity, competitive HER side reaction and low electrochemical stability. Increasing the overpotential could enhance the reaction kinetics by overcoming the activation barrier; however, it leads to an unfavorable competing HER. To solve this dilemma, SACs with uniform active sites and geometric structures have recently been developed for efficient and highly selective CO2RRs. As an example, Wallace and colleagues [105] demonstrated that Sn nanoparticles on N-doped carbons could drive the efficient production of formate with a FE of 62% at an overpotential of 690 mV. At a considerably lower overpotential of 490 mV, the Sn-SACs led to the conversion of CO2 to CO with a FE of 91%. Recently, Liu et al. [44] reported that Ni-SAs on N-doped graphene could efficiently convert CO2 to CO with a high specific current of 350 A g−1 and TOF of 14800 h−1 at a mild overpotential of 0.61 V with a Faraday efficiency (FE) of 97%. Impressively, 98% of the initial current of Ni-SACs was retained even after 100 h of continuous reaction at a current density of 22 mA cm−1. The catalytic active sites of Ni-SACs were clearly identified to be the monovalent uncommon Ni(I) atomic center by operando XAS and photoelectron spectroscopy measurements (Fig. 12 a). In a recent work, Choi et al. [106] investigated the catalytic sites of Ni-SACs for the CO2RR in detail. Both Ni-N4 with a porphyrin structure and Ni–Cl–N3O were prepared for comparative study of their structure–function in the CO2RR. For Ni–SACs with four N coordination, the energy barrier was much more unfavorable for the CO2RR in comparison with that of Ni–Cl–N3O. According to advanced spectroscopic and computational studies, broken ligand-field symmetry is the key for active CO2RR (Fig. 12b and c), which further indicates the prominent effect of the local environment on the SACs. In the continuous search for high-performance CO2RR SAC-HDPC electrocatalysts, Hu and colleagues [30] recently reported a Fe3+–N–C electrocatalyst that exhibited a partial current density of 94 mA cm−2 at an overpotential of 0.34 V with a FEco of 90%. These performance metrics are considerably higher than those of reported nonprecious metal catalysts and even comparable to state-of-the-art Au-based catalysts. The active sites were identified as pyrrolic N coordinated Fe3+. It was found that pyridinic N-coordinated Fe2+ displayed lower than an order of magnitude catalytic activity in comparison with Fe3+–N–C. Similarly, Li et al. [107] demonstrated that the coordination environment of Co-SACs plays a crucial role in determining the performance of the CO2RR. Atomically dispersed Co with 2 coordinated N atoms could achieve both high selectivity and activity with a FEco of 94% and a current density of 18.1 mA cm−2 at an overpotential of 0.52 V. In contrast, Co-SACs with 5 coordinated N atoms showed a FEco of nearly 100% at −0.73 and −0.79 V. The DFT calculation demonstrated that the 5 N coordinated Co can rapidly form reaction intermediates and desorb CO during the CO2RR (Fig. 12d and e) [39]. These results clearly revealed the key roles of the local environments of SACs on their performances. In addition to CO as the major product of electrochemical CO2RRs, He et al. [108] recently showed that Cu-SAs on hole-laden carbon nanofiber membranes could generate nearly pure methanol with a partial current density of −93 mA cm−2 and a FE of 44% in the liquid phase. According to DFT calculations, the catalytic centers (Cu–N4) have a positive free energy of 0.12 eV, which is an endergonic step. At this stage, the adsorbed *CO intermediate could be further reduced to methanol. Meanwhile, the porous structure is favorable for mass transfer and thus largely enhances the catalytic efficiency of the CO2RR. In a recent exciting example, Chen et al. [109] reported the formation of acetone with a FE of 36.7% and a production rate of 336.1 μg h−1 utilizing Cu-SA on N-doped carbons as electrocatalysts. Cu atoms with four pyrrole-N atoms were identified as catalytic sites, which can reduce the reaction free energies required for the activation of CO2. Taken together, these considerations indicate that SAC-HDPCs have the potential for practical implementation of CO2RRs in aqueous media to produce various value-added chemicals. 4.1.5 N2 Fixation Approximately 500 Mt of nitrogen-based fertilizer made from ammonia is produced globally every year by the Haber-Bosch process [8]. Fertilizers have enhanced the productivity of agricultural land by a factor of four. In the context of greenhouse gas-induced global warming and climate change, it is significant to note that the amount of CO2 equivalents released into the atmosphere from the production of ammonia is 400 Mt per year, with 12 Gt per year CO2 equivalents produced from the entire food chain. This represents approximately 1.5% of all greenhouse gas emissions. Surely, there has to be a greener and simpler way to make NH3! In this context, the electrochemical reduction of N2 under ambient conditions with H2O as a hydrogen source is promising [110]. Recently, Xin et al. [111] constructed Mo-SA on N-doped porous carbons for efficient NRR. Due to their intrinsic hierarchically porous structures and high density of active sites, the Mo-SACs displayed a remarkable NH3 yield of approximately 34 ± 3.6 μgNH3 mgCat −1h−1 and a FE of 14.6% ± 1.6% in 0.1 M KOH media. Zeng et al. [112] demonstrated one of the most active Ru-SACs for the NRR with a FE of 29.6% and a partial current density of −0.13 mA cm−2 for NH3 production at a low overpotential of −0.2 V. Impressively, the production of NH3 reached as high as 120.9 μgNH3 mgCat −1h−1. To further understand the high catalytic performance of Ru-SACs, N2 temperature-programmed desorption for Ru-SACs and their NP counterparts was conducted. The binding strength of N2 on Ru-SACs was much stronger than that of their NP counterparts. DFT calculation results showed that N2 dissociation on Ru-SACs has a much lower energy barrier than that of Ru(101), which facilitates the NRR process. In 2019, Qiao et al. [113] reported detailed computational work to unveil the intrinsic electrocatalytic activity of SA on N-doped carbons for the NRR. In their work, 60 models with 20 different metals were constructed. Based on the calculation results, Co–, Ru- and W-SAs on carbon nitride (Co@g-C3N4, Ru@g-C3N4 and W@g-C3N4, respectively) were identified with the lowest limiting potentials. The protonation process is considered the most thermodynamically uphill step. All of these candidates displayed rather reduced free energy changes. By plotting the limiting potentials as a function of the Gibbs free energy of *NNH (ΔG NNH*) and *NH2 (ΔG NH*), it was found that the activities of various metal-SAs on different N-doped carbon supports are different. In the activity peak region, g–C3N4-supported SAs displayed better intensity than other N-doped carbons (three and four N-coordinated SACs). Among all of the studied samples, Ru@g–C3N4 was located very close to the maximum activity region, suggesting it to be the most promising electrocatalyst for the NRR. In addition to the catalytic activity, the stability of each catalyst was also calculated, in which the four N-coordinated SACs displayed the highest stability, followed by g–C3N4 and three N-coordinated SACs. This work provided useful information for the rational design of highly active and stable electrocatalysts for the NRR. 4.2 Energy conversion devices 4.2.1 Fuel cell and Zn-Air battery The key to achieving practical energy conversion devices is to develop high-performance electrocatalysts with outstanding activity and stability [27,114,115]. Current commercially available catalysts are heavily based on platinum-group nanomaterials. Nevertheless, the high cost of Pt precludes the large-scale application of platinum-based devices, thus calling for Pt-group-metal-free catalysts or immensely decreasing the Pt content in the catalysts as low-cost alternatives. To this end, one alternative solution is to downsize Pt nanocatalysts to Pt-SACs. Liu et al. [45] reported that Pt-SAs supported on N-doped carbons for H2/O2 fuel cells with a low Pt loading of 0.09 mgPt cm−2 exhibited a high power density up to 680 mW cm−2. In addition, within a 200 h stability test at 0.5 VRHE, the Pt-SAs@N-doped carbons still displayed 74% and 90% of the current at 80 and 70 °C, respectively. The high performance and excellent stability of Pt-SACs were attributed to the abundant exposed active sites (Pt-pyridinic N x ). In addition to Pt-based electrocatalysts, TM-SACs have also exhibited excellent performance in fuel cell devices. Wu et al. [116] fabricated Fe-SAs on N-doped carbons as cathodes by the direct pyrolysis of a zeolitic imidazolate framework for acidic polymer electrolyte fuel cells. With fine tuning of the precursors, the Fe content was optimized to be 1.5 at% with the FeN4 configuration and free of any clusters and NPs. Under the same operation conditions, the Fe-SACs showed a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.88 ± 0.01 V vs. RHE in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte. In H2-air fuel cell, the current density was measured to be 145 mA cm−2 at a voltage of 0.8 V. In another work, Shui et al. [72] employed a hierarchically porous Fe–N4/carbon electrocatalyst with a BET surface area of 650 m2 g−1 in proton exchange membrane fuel cells, achieving a high current density of 129 mA cm−2 at 0.8 V under 1.0 bar H2–O2 pressure. The peak power density of 1.18 W cm−2 was achieved under 2.5 bar H2–O2 pressure. Such excellent PEMFC performance was attributed to the abundant exposed active sites originating from the large external surface area and porosity of the carbon supporter. Although Fe-SAC-based fuel cells have shown encouraging performance, the undesirable Fenton reaction generated from H2O2 production significantly affects the stability of the long-term operational stability of fuel cell devices. In this regard, Mn-SAC-based fuel cells were well developed with remarkable stability and resistance against corrosion [64]. The Mn–N–C catalysts showed comparable performance to that of Fe–N–C catalysts but significantly enhanced stability in acidic environments. More recently, atomically dispersed p-block element Sn on N-doped carbon that displayed a 40%–50% higher current density than Fe catalysts at cell voltages below 0.7 V in a hydrogen-air fuel cell was reported [79]. These Sn-SACs displayed high selectivity toward the four-electron pathway and were found to be inactive to undesirable Fenton reactions. With the continued development of SAC-HDPC electrocatalysts, replacement of the high-cost platinum-group nanocatalysts and improvement of the stability of fuel cells is achievable. 4.2.2 Zn-air battery Driven by OER and ORR processes, metal-air batteries have been regarded as promising candidates for next-generation green energy conversion and storage devices because of their low cost and high energy density [117]. In 2016, Wu et al. [103] demonstrated that Fe-SAs on N- and S-codoped hierarchical carbon layers could be effectively employed as bifunctional catalysts under alkaline conditions. The catalysts displayed remarkable performance with a maximum power density of 102.7 mW cm−2 and a high limiting current density of 6.68 mA cm−2 at a potential of 0.2 V. In another work, Zhang et al. [118] prepared Co-SAs on N/O-doped carbons for rechargeable Zn-air batteries. When integrated into a flexible solid Zn-air battery, a high open-circuit voltage of 1.44 V and a stable discharge voltage of 1.19 V were achieved. The rechargeable liquid Zn-air battery displayed a maximum power density as high as 152 mW cm−2. Zhu et al. [119] prepared Fe-SACs from the direct pyrolysis of a FeCl3-encapsulated porphyra precursor. The obtained electrocatalysts displayed ultrahigh ORR and impressive OER catalytic activity. Employing Fe-SACs as electrodes for Zn-air batteries, a high-power density of 225.1 mW cm−2 and lower charging-discharging overpotential comparable to commercial Pt/C were achieved. Recently, Wu et al. [120] developed a simple method to directly transform Cu oxide bulk into Cu-SACs through gas transportation at 1500 K. These developed Cu-SACs displayed excellent ORR performance with a half-wave potential of 0.92 V vs. RHE. Correspondingly, the Cu-SAC-based Zn-air battery exhibited a maximum power density up to 280 mW cm−2 with robust stability over 45 h. 4.2.3 Lithium-sulfur battery Li-S batteries have attracted increasing attention as promising energy storage candidates to replace conventional Li-ion batteries due to their much higher theoretical specific capacity, gravimetric energy density and volumetric energy density [121,122]. The unique two-electron-transfer reaction between S and lithium generates a much higher energy density than the intercalation mechanism of Li-ion batteries. However, during the discharge process, the polysulfides could be dissolved in ether electrolyte and detached from the cathode. This process is often referred to as the “shuttle effect”, which is detrimental to stable Li-S batteries. In addition, the sluggish kinetics of polysulfide conversion to Li2S2/Li2S and undesirable formation of Li dendrites largely hindered their real-life application. In this context, intense study on Li is focused on the development of high-performance and stable cathode materials. SACs with maximum metal utilization not only boost the intrinsic sluggish Li polysulfide transformation but also have an intrinsically low weight density, which is ideal for loading additional sulfur. Moreover, the uniformly dispersed SAs acting as lithiophilic sites could effectively reduce the nucleation overpotential, thereby preventing the formation of Li dendrites. To fully understand the performance of SACs in Li-S batteries, Cui et al. [123] rationalized an efficient SAC design pathway for Li-S batteries by combining theoretical calculations and experimental results (Fig. 13 a). In this work, the decomposition barriers of Li2S on different SACs (Fe, Mn, Ru, Zn, Co, Cu, V and Ag) were calculated to determine the catalytic activity of S species. As shown in Fig. 13(b), for SACs, more electron density was observed between S and the metal atoms, which can weaken the L−S bond, effectually decreasing the decomposition barriers of Li2S. According to the calculation, V-SACs displayed the lowest decomposition barrier of 1.10 eV and highest adsorption energy of 3.38 eV toward Li2S6, thereby suppressing the “shuttle effect” in the battery. In the experimental study, the S-loaded V-SACs as cathodes in Li-S batteries exhibited a superior discharge capacity of 1230 mA h g−1 and a capacity decay of 0.073% per cycle after 400 cycles. Recently, Zhao et al. [124] developed a double-end binding site cathode for Li-S batteries. In the engineered cathode, ZnS NPs and Co-SACs were dispersed on a macroporous host and assembled into a 1-A-h-level pouch cell. This Li-S battery delivered a cell specific energy of > 300 Wh kg−1 with a coulombic efficiency > 95% for 80 cycles. In their theoretical calculation, it was found that Li+ was bonded to the ZnS NPs, while Sn 2− was coordinated with single sited Co atoms (Fig. 13c). Such a unique combination mode of Li+ and Sn 2− at dual sites endows the device with excellent performance. Furthermore, according to the relative free energy landscape for the discharging process from S8 to Li2S, the developed double-end binding site cathodes displayed a more favorable reaction process (Fig. 13d). With the aid of atomically dispersed Co-SACs, the growth of Li dendrites was significantly suppressed [125]. This is ascribed to the efficient kinetic conversion of Li-polysulfide and restriction of their dissolution in the electrochemical process. 5 Conclusions and outlook In this review, we summarized the latest research on the development of SACs on HDPCs for electrochemical energy conversion. Due to favorable heteroatom doping, high conductivity, porosity and low cost, SAC-HDPCs have shown great promise as electrocatalysts for various energy conversion applications. By rationally tailoring the heteroatoms or their configuration, the electronic structures of SAs on HDPCs can be utterly different, thereby leading to completely different electrochemical activities and selectivities on demand. With numerous merits associated with HDPCs as substrates, it is believed that SAC-HDPCs could be potentially significant in various energy-related areas. At beginning, the different techniques to characterize SAC-HDPCs were generalized. In particular, scanning electron microscopy and APT could be utilized to directly visualize isolated metal atoms, which provide geometric information on the catalytic sites. With the aid of the synchrotron radiation technique, the exact electronic structures and active sites of SACs could be accurately interpreted. More importantly, with the recent development of various in situ/operando characterization techniques, it has become possible to directly monitor catalytic reactions during their operations. In this regard, the dynamic behaviors of both the geometric structure and electronic environment of SACs at the atomic scale can be well understood, thus providing insight toward task-specific high-performance catalysts. The construction of SACs relies on successfully trapping the (semi)-metal atoms within the substrates, whether from defects or coordination. In HDPCs, both heteroatoms and porosity (defects) can be utilized to stabilize (semi)-metal atoms and tailor the electronic structures of the active centers. Strategies including wet impregnation, direct pyrolysis and selective deposition have shown great promise in the development of SAC-HDPCs. These methods require effective coordination or defects to stabilize the metal atoms to prevent aggregation. At the same time, the newly emerging p-block elements such as Se could effectively form stable C–Se bonds within the carbon matrix, thereby forming uniformly dispersed Se SA on carbons with high loading content. As mentioned previously, SACs are similar to complex homogenous systems, as the catalytic center can be modulated by a specific ligand. In SACs, the local environment plays a crucial role in determining the activity and selectivity of the catalysts. By paring the single (semi)-metal atoms with different heteroatoms or even same heteroatoms with different configuration, distinctive activity and selectivity of SAC-HDPCs can be expected. Therefore, by judicious choice of carbon precursor, appropriate metal sources and processing techniques, high-performance SAC-HDPCs electrode can be readily engineered to mitigate, or potentially address the current energy and environment issues. Considering that applications of SAC-HDPCs are, in most cases, focused on electrocatalytic energy conversion fields, the integrated membrane-like shape of HDPC-SACs might be fascinating since they can be directly utilized as electrodes, avoiding the traditionally complicated processing of powdery counterparts by gluing with the use of electronically insulating polymer binders (i.e., Nafion or PVDF) [126]. Preparation of SAC-HDPCs via the carbonization of organic compounds is a widely accepted strategy, which is considered to have a “bad reputation” in terms of their uncontrollable carbon structure. High-temperature pyrolysis typically breaks down polymeric chains and always results in cracks. In this regard, to achieve practical membrane-like SAC-HDPCs, two key issues need to be considered: one is how to prepare a suitable polymer porous membrane template (PPMT), enabling “morphology-maintaining” carbonization of the PPMT precursor leading to membrane-like SAC-HDPC [124]. In this process, another point is associated with what carbonization craft will be employed since it is crucial to maintain the integrity of SAC-HDPCs in the carbonization process. In SAC-HDPCs, the loading content of the single atom in the SAC-HDPC is greatly restricted to inhibit the aggregation of single atoms during high-temperature pyrolysis. The low content of single atoms in SAC-HDPC is not conducive to meeting the requirements of practical applications (>1 wt% metal content) [86]. Therefore, from the viewpoint of real-world application, challenges remain in the quest to explore scalable, efficient synthetic routes to SAC-HDPCs with high single-atom loading. One can believe that by employing different synthetic methods and elements to obtain a variety of SAC-HDPCs for special usage, the possibilities are temptingly vast. The field of SAC-HDPCs is rapidly expanding. The applications of these systems have only been slightly touched upon in this article, namely, electrocatalytic energy conversion. The potential that many of these systems display in a wide range of applications clearly provides considerable incentive for further work. Yue shao got his B.S. degree (Honours) at the University of Prince Edward Island, Canada. He then worked with Prof. Douglas Stephan at the University of Toronto in frustrated Lewis pairs chemistry. Later, he continued his research with Prof. Hong Wang at Nankai University, China, on poly(ionic liquid)-derived functional materials. He is currently a master student at Tsinghua University and studies soft Janus nanoparticles and their self-organized nanostructures. Zhengtai Zha is a Ph.D. candidate at the Nankai University. He received a B.S. degree in from the Shenyang Jianzhu University and an M.S. degree at the Chongqing University, China. His research interest is in the preparation of poly(ionic liquid)-based functional porous membranes for energy and environmental applications. Hong Wang received his Ph.D. degree from the Lab of Advanced Materials, Fudan University, in 2013. After multiple research stays at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (Hong Kong), King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (Kingdom of Saudi Arabia), Max Planck Institute of Colloids and interfaces (Germany), and University of Toronto (Canada), he joined Nankai University as a professor in China (2017). His current research interest is exclusively in the area of poly(ionic liquid)-based functional materials (including carbons) science.

coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalysts play a crucial role in the development of renewable energy conversion and storage nanotechnologies. The unique advantages of heteroatom-doped porous carbon-supported single-atom electrocatalysts (SAC-HDPCs) are clear. These SAC-HDPCs exhibit outstanding activity, selectivity and stability due to their distinct electronic structure, satisfactory conductivity, controllable porosity and heteroatom-doping effect. Rapid and significant developments involving the synthesis, characterization, and structure-property-function relationship of SAC-HDPCs have been made in recent years. In this review, we describe recent research efforts involving advanced (in situ) characterization techniques, innovative synthetic strategies, and electrochemical energy conversion examples of SAC-HDPCs. The electrocatalytic performance of SAC-HDPCs is further considered at an atomic level, and the mechanisms underlying this performance are also discussed in detail. We expect that these analyses and deductions will be useful for the design of new materials and may help to establish a foundation for the design of future SAC-HDPCs.
